ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] Thanks/ further question about flame1
ygData.msgSnippet: A duplicate reaction means that the reactant and product stoichiometric coefficients are the same (or differ by a constant factor) for the two reactions.

A duplicate reaction means that the reactant and product stoichiometric 
coefficients are the same (or differ by a constant factor) for the two 
reactions.  Cantera assumes this is an error unless you tell it that 
you meant to do this by adding  options = ['duplicate'].  Not all 
H2-O2-N2-Ar mechanisms have duplicate reactions, but this one (obtained 
by editing GRI-Mech 3.0) does.


On May 22, 2005, at 1:50 PM, aedahoe wrote:

>
> Many thanks Dave. It works now.
>
> Further question:
>
> Some of the reactions in the kinetic
> scheme are tagged with [options = 'duplicate'].
> These reactions appear twice but with different
> kinetic parameters. Why is this? When I look
> at the kinetic scheme (H2-O2-N2-Ar) by Marinov, Westbrook & Pitz,
> there are no duplicate reactions.
>
> Arief
>
>
>
> --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
>> Arief,
>>
>>> (1) why are there no thermodynamic and reaction
>>> data in it, as in the case of h2o2.xml?
>>
>> In the file I sent you, I prefaced the species entry
> with "gri30: ",
>> and also the reactions entry.  This means that Cantera will look
> for
>> these species / reactions in file gri30.xml, instead of in the
> local
>> file.  The gri30.xml file comes with Cantera.
>>
>>> (2) what is the role of the file h2o2.xml? Is
>>> it an output file, or is it being used during the
>>> flame calculations?
>>
>> When Cantera reads a .cti input file, it first converts it to
> another
>> format and gives it the extension .xml.  The xml file is then read
> to
>> build the objects used in the application program.  You can regard
> the
>> .xml file as an internal intermediate file that you don't have to
> worry
>> about.  Alternatively, once you have created the xml file, you can
> use
>> it in place of the cti file in your program.  This is useful if
> you
>> want to run Cantera on a machine that does not have Python
> installed,
>> since Python is required to do the cti -> xml conversion but not
> to
>> read the xml file.
>>
>>> (3) I modified the file h2o2.cti, such that it contains
>>> ideal_gas(name = "ohmech",
>>>       elements = " O  H  Ar  N ",
>>>       species = """ H2  H  O  O2  OH  H2O  HO2  H2O2  AR  N2 """,
>>>       reactions = "all",
>>>       transport = "Mix",
>>>       initial_state = state(temperature = 300.0,
>>>       pressure = OneAtm)    ).
>>> However, when I perform the flame calculation I get
>>> the error message species "N2" unknown. Why do I get
>>> this error mesage?
>>>
>> Because it is looking for a definition of species "N2" in the
> local
>> file, but not finding one.
>>
>>> PS. To replace AR by N2 I redefined AR in the .cti file,
>>> such that it contains 2 nitrogen atoms and accompanying
>>> physical data. This seems to work.
>> That works. Or you can just add a species entry for N2 in addition
> to
>> AR.
>>>
>>>
>> Dave
>
